message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of disrupted vision, itchy bumps, and black hyperpigmented nodules with edema and palpable lymphadenopathy suggest that the patient has onchocerciasis, which is transmitted by black flies. Ivermectin is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest that she has onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, which is transmitted by black flies. Ivermectin is the most effective treatment for this disease. Diethylcarbamazine and mebendazole are used to treat other parasitic infections, and nifurtimox is used to treat Chagas disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest that she may have onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, which is transmitted by black flies. Ivermectin is the most effective medication for treating onchocerciasis. Diethylcarbamazine can be used as well, but it is less effective than ivermectin. Mebendazole and Nifurtimox are not used to treat onchocerciasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The black hyperpigmented nodules with edema and palpable lymphadenopathy suggest onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, which is transmitted by black flies. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is Ivermectin, which is used to treat onchocerciasis. Diethylcarbamazine is also used to treat onchocerciasis, but is less effective and not recommended for use in patients with severe onchocerciasis. Mebendazole and Nifurtimox are used to treat other parasitic infections, but are not effective against onchocerciasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest Onchocerciasis, also called River blindness, which is transmitted by black flies. Ivermectin is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this disease. Diethylcarbamazine is used to treat another parasitic disease called lymphatic filariasis. Mebendazole is used to treat intestinal worm infections. Nifurtimox is used to treat Chagas disease, which is caused by a different parasite transmitted by insects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the history of transmission by black flies suggest the patient has onchocerciasis. Among the options, Ivermectin is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms and the mode of transmission, the disease is likely onchocerciasis, or river blindness, caused by Onchocerca volvulus transmitted by black flies. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is Ivermectin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The black hyperpigmented nodules and the history of disrupted vision suggest the patient has onchocerciasis, which is transmitted by black flies. Ivermectin is the most appropriate therapy for the patient as it targets the microfilariae and early-stage larvae of the parasite. Diethylcarbamazine can also be used but is less effective against the adult worms. Mebendazole and Nifurtimox are not used for onchocerciasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the mode of transmission of the disease suggest onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, which is caused by a parasite transmitted by black flies. Ivermectin is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this disease. Diethylcarbamazine is also used for onchocerciasis, but it is more effective against the microfilariae stage rather than the adult worm stage. Mebendazole is used for intestinal helminth infections, and Nifurtimox is used for Chagas disease.

The symptoms and finding of black hyperpigmented nodules with edema and palpable lymphadenopathy suggest onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, which is a parasitic infection transmitted by black flies. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is Ivermectin.
